reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s key “trade helps, threats hurt” story in sections 3.1–3.4, which matters to the essay’s conditional optimism about partial convergence + moral trade, but it’s not the whole thesis (the essay also argues against WAM-convergence and discusses other blockers), so centrality is moderate. The argument has some bite as a request for an explanation: if superintelligence enables strong commitment/contracting, why can’t it also enable robust anti-extortion coordination? However it doesn’t actually refute the essay’s concern, because (a) enforceable bilateral contracts don’t imply a globally stable, mutually agreeable security regime; (b) credible threat-making can itself be strengthened by commitment tech; and (c) the essay already flags that it’s “not obvious” that stable threat-preventing legal systems exist, so the tension is partly anticipated. The critique is mostly correct in identifying an under-argued asymmetry, but overstates it by implying defensive coordination should be straightforward if contracting is. It is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little to no filler.
title: Coordination technologies should neutralize threats as effectively as they enable trade
